awd_titl_txt: Course-Based Undergraduate Research for All: Preparing the Future STEM Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
Opportunities to conduct authentic research improve students' understanding of science and promote their self-identification as scientists. Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) allow many more students to be exposed to authentic research than the traditional mentor-mentee, apprenticeship-style approach to undergraduate research. The investigators will develop CUREs in which all STEM majors in the School of Mathematical and Natural Sciences at the West campus of Arizona State University (ASU) will enroll. The courses will focus on research questions, and in them the students will become scientists -- generating hypotheses, developing protocols, performing experiments, generating data, and analyzing the results. By designing interdisciplinary CURE modules, testing them at ASU West, and disseminating them widely, the project will enhance an evidence-based pedagogical approach that will improve the education of the future STEM workforce.

The CUREs to be developed will focus on topics in food science, remediation, cell biology, and population dynamics. Tentative module titles include "Native Bees of Arizona: Bee Species Diversity and Relative Abundance," "Phytotoxicity and Phytoremediation of Mine Site Soils," and "Analysis of Ethanol Production and Flocculation in Brewer's Yeast." All of the modules will be geared toward data generation, analysis, and publication and will advance the understanding of their research topics. The investigators will develop pedagogical methodology that integrates all aspects of the scientific method -- namely, hypothesis generation, experimental execution, and data analysis -- and will analyze the ability of the CUREs to increase students' interest, abilities, and retention in science. The methodology will incorporate a "common course outline," which will standardize the teaching of common components of scientific inquiry and will be flexible enough to be applied to diverse research topics. To encourage the use of CUREs by faculty at other institutions, the investigators will sponsor workshops on the nature of CUREs in general, their particular CURE model and modules, and assessment techniques.

por.por_cntn:
Students best learn science by doing science.  The traditional way of students learning science is either by rote memorization, canned laboratory exercises, or research experiences in individual faculty?s laboratories.  Unfortunately, with the explosion of growth of STEM majors and limited institutional resources in some universities, it is harder than ever for students to do authentic science.  The Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) is an alternative to individual research experiences, in that students enroll in a course and perform authentic research as a team.  

 We have developed, implemented, and assessed Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs), in which all STEM majors from the School of Mathematical and Natural Sciences in the New College of Arizona State University would enroll and synergistically learn from each other.  CUREs are rapidly becoming a model for undergraduate education in which students enroll in a course that is focused on a research question, and the students themselves generate hypotheses, develop protocols, generate the data, and analyze the outcomes. We leveraged the interdisciplinary nature of the School, which encompasses all of the STEM disciplines. We created a common course framework that is applicable to a wide variety of research topics and helps support novice implementers of a CURE. 

The iCURE project positively impacted a very diverse group of students.  The participating students  were predominantly first generation students (48.6%), 59% female, 29% Hispanic, with high financial need (66% Pell grant recipients).  Interdisciplinary Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experiences are a cost- and time-effective method to expose all students to authentic research experiences.

All documents are available here  https://sites.google.com/asu.edu/icure-workshop/home 

All videos are available here https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCRQMSxAtwWLqqjEhmIdq2vQ 

This project has been successful in engaging broader impacts, such as 

(1) Advancing Discovery and Understanding While Promoting Teaching, Training and Learning, as students were involved in bona fide research projects developing their own hypotheses and testing them within a larger framework of a course.

 (2) Sharing CURES and the Common Course Outline with the Broader Scientific Community through presentations, publications, a workshop, and videos, as described above.

(3) Broadening Participation of Underrepresented Groups, as the demographics of the students in the iCURE skewed towards first generation and underrepresented students.

(4) Improved Well-Being in Society by supporting student research into environmental issues, by disseminating findings of such research, and by teaching students about the importance of environmental issues in our society.

Intellectual merits of the project include both published research of student projects and design and implementation of a CURE structure that will allow anyone who wishes to teach a CURE to do so with copious support.
